thread.title: Britain set to leave EU by summer 2019 as Theresa May will trigger Article 50 in early 2017
thread.title_full: Britain set to leave EU by summer 2019 as Theresa May will trigger Article 50 in early 2017

author: Simon Meechan
title: Britain set to leave EU by summer 2019 as Theresa May will trigger Article 50 in early 2017
text:
Britain set to leave EU by summer 2019 as Theresa May will trigger Article 50 in early 2017 11:31, 2 Oct 2016 The Prime Minister will unveil the full plans at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham later today Share Get daily news by email Prime Minister Theresa May 
Britain looks set to leave the European Union by summer 2019 after the Prime Minister revealed she will trigger the two-year Brexit process early next year. 
Theresa May told BBC One’s Andrew Marr show she will invoke Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty by the end of March 2017. 
She will formally announce the plans in her speech at the Conservative Party conference in Birmingham later today. 
Speaking to Andrew Marr, Mrs May said: “As you know, I have been saying that we wouldn’t trigger it before the end of this year so that we get some preparation in place. 
“But yes, I will be saying in my speech today that we will trigger (Article 50) before the end of March next year.” Read More EU Referendum: What is Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty and what does it mean? 
The Prime Minister will also unveil plans to let Britain pick and choose the EU regulations it wants. 
She will tell fellow Tories that a “Great Repeal Bill” will strike out the 1972 European Communities Act, which made Britain subject to the then European Economic Community’s laws. 
This will let Westminster pick the European laws it wants to keep, remove or amend. 
Conservative MP for Berwick, Anne-Marie Trevelyan, tweeted her delight at Mrs May’s revelation. 
She wrote: “Great News! Plans for 1972 Act repeal set in motion by PM. All that campaigning to get control back worth the fight!” 
Mrs May’s announcement follows June’s EU Referendum, where 52% of the country voted in favour of Leaving the European Union. 
The majority of voters in Sunderland, South Tyneside, North Tyneside, Gateshead, County Durham and Northumberland backed the Leave campaign. In Newcastle, 50.7% voted in favour of remaining in the EU. More on the EU Referendum
